thread.title: WA’s first residential airpark takes off with aviation enthusiasts
thread.title_full: WA’s first residential airpark takes off with aviation enthusiasts

author: ANNABEL HENNESSY Real Estate Reporter
title: WA’s first residential airpark takes off with aviation enthusiasts
text:
MOST neighbours compete over who has the flashiest car on the street.
But at the Myrup Fly-In Estate, residents compare notes on their aircraft.
Homeowners at WA’s first residential “airpark”, located in Esperance, are able to roll their planes into their driveways at the end of a busy day — storing planes in their hangars at their homes. The one place in WA where nobody complains about flight noise, the estate has two runways of 1200m and 900m.
Noel Willing, 71, was part of a syndicate group of five farming families who pushed to have the 117ha estate approved as an airpark in the 1990s. Estate guard dog Alfie in uniform. Picture: Travis Anderson. Source: Supplied
Now, 20 years down the track, Mr Willing and his wife, Joanne, are set to become just the fifth family to move into the quirky southern community.
“The problem for many flyers is it can be difficult to find somewhere to store a plane that will allow you to fly regularly,” Mr Willing said.
“Airparks have been popular in the US for a long time because they allow aviation enthusiasts to take off whenever they want.”
Builder David Wohling, who is raising three kids on the estate, said the unique property allowed him to share his love of planes with neighbours.
“It’s a great atmosphere, everyone has something in common,” Mr Wohling, who has built seven planes, said.
“My eight-year-old son loves it, he gets to watch (the planes) take off every day.”
In Denmark, 423km southeast of Perth, a second residential airpark is being created with 10 “house and hangar lots” and a 1200m runway. Real estate agent John Ricketts is selling the final four lots for $170,000 each and said the blocks were the most unusual properties of his career.
“It’s been buyers from every walk of life, Denmark locals, retirees, Perth professionals and even a bloke from Silicon Valley,” Mr Ricketts said.
“They haven’t necessarily been the super-elite, just ordinary people who love to fly.”
Originally published as WA’s first residential airpark takes off Increase
